column1: Garowe is situated in the Nugaal Valley

column5: 300 feet) above sea level on the north

column2: Garowe and much of northeastern Somalia were an integral part of the Majeerteen Sultanate
column4: cousin of Sultan Yusuf Ali Kenadid of the Sultanate of Hobyo.

column1: The city would later be incorporated into Italian Somaliland during the colonial period.

column2: Garowe was made a district center of Bosaso. The city would subsequently be reassigned in the early 1970s as the regional capital of an area consisting of Las Anod and Eyl. Straddling the Nugal Valley
column3: this new administrative division would be named Nugal.Following the outbreak of the civil war in 1991
column4: a homegrown constitutional conference was held in Garowe in 1998 over a period of three months. Attended by the area's political elite

column1: Garowe has a hot desert climate (Köppen climate classification BWh). As such
column2: the weather is generally hot
column3: sunny and dry. Coldest average temperatures occur during the months of November to February
column4: when thermometer readings range from 23 to 25 °C (73 to 77 °F). The weather slowly heats up in the spring
column5: as the April rainy season begins. Average temperatures later reach a maximum of around 41 °C over the summer period. Come September
column6: a gradual cooling starts to set in again. Annual rainfall is low
column7: averaging 123 mm (5.25 in). The sky is usually clear and bright throughout the year.

column1: Garowe is the third largest city in Puntland after Bosaso and Galkayo. Situated in the Nugal province in the geographical center of the region
column2: it is the seat of the regional parliament
column3: the presidential palace and government ministries.

column1: Garowe is traversed by a 750 km north–south highway. It connects major cities in the northern part of the country
column2: such as Bosaso and Galkayo
column3: with towns in the south. In 2012
column4: the Puntland Highway Authority (PHA) completed rehabilitation work on the central artery linking Garowe with Galkayo. The transportation body also began an upgrade and repair project in June 2012 on the large Garowe–Bosaso Highway. Additionally
column5: plans are in the works to construct new roads connecting littoral towns in the region to the main thoroughfare.In October 2014
column6: Puntland President Abdiweli Mohamed Ali laid down the foundation for a new highway connecting the presidential palace in Garowe with various other parts of the administrative capital. Financing for the project was provided by the Puntland government. According to the Head of the Puntland Highway Authority Mohamud Abdinur Adan
column7: the new thoroughfare aims to facilitate local transportation and movement. Puntland Minister of Public Works Mohamed Hersi also indicated that the Puntland authorities plan to build and repair other roads linking to the regional urban centers. In March 2015
column8: Puntland President Ali inaugurated additional newly built
column9: paved roads in Garowe. The streets were constructed by a local company through the JPLG program. Puntland President Ali also inaugurated another new two kilometer asphalt road in Garowe
column10: a construction project that was implemented by the municipal authorities. According to the Nugal province Governor Abdullahi Aw-Isse
column11: the highway links the city's eastern neighborhoods with the downtown area
column12: and aims to buttress the ongoing local infrastructure and commercial development initiatives. It is the eighth bitumen road completed in the town since 2014
column13: with the Garowe municipality aiming to convert to asphalt all of the city's streets.In March 2015
column14: Ali in conjunction with EU Ambassador to Somalia Michele Cervone d’Urso and German Ambassador to Somalia Andreas Peschke also launched the Sustainable Road Maintenance Project. Part of the New Deal Compact for Somalia
column15: the initiative's implementation is facilitated by 17.75 million Euros and 3 million Euros provided by the EU and Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ)
column17: the project aims to renovate the highway between Garowe and Galkayo
column18: including funding refurbishments on the damaged segments of the road and construction of check dams and flood control structures. The initiative also involves a routine annual maintenance program
column23: the project will offer policy support to the Puntland Ministry of Public Works and the Puntland Highway Authority
column24: and  local contractors will receive on-the-job training to upgrade their skills.Local air transport needs are served by Garowe International Airport
column25: a major airport situated about 12 km from the city center. It was officially opened in 2010 under the aegis of the Ministry for Civil Aviation and Airports. The first phase of the airport's construction was completed through a public-private partnership over a period of seven years
column26: with the Garowe-based Mubarak construction company having assisted significantly in completing the project. The airport also attempts to adhere to the air transport standards established by the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO).In March 2015
column27: a business meeting was held in Dubai to evaluate tenders from various firms that are bidding for a contract to build a new airport in Garowe. The construction project was organized by the Puntland aviation and finance ministries
column28: with the Kuwait Fund providing assistance. Four companies were reportedly awarded the contract
column29: with the tender winner(s) scheduled to be officially announced in April of the year.
